Student Wellness Screening Reminder! Parents of students attending in-person school, or of students who enter our buildings for tutoring or small group activities, will be required to complete the wellness screening for their children, and to certify that they are symptom-free PRIOR to boarding a bus and/or arriving at our schools. If students are not certified that they are healthy before coming to school, they will be pulled for temperature and symptom checks in a separate area as they arrive.

Parents can easily complete their child's wellness screening by downloading the Skyward app from the Apple Store or Google Play, or going online to Skyward Family Access and certifying their health under the "Wellness Screenings" headline in the message area.

Here's a link to a tutorial on how to complete this each day that your child is going to school: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TqxEjxm4ANvTBcz9411s5b1Bw9qWg_i2yaDxZO1OgYQ/edit?usp=sharing

Glenwood High School
July 10 at 5:21 PM ¬∑

As part of our multi-event graduation ceremony, Glenwood High School will be continuing to celebrate our seniors with a drive-in screening of the 2020 Graduation Ceremony at GHS. Class of 2020 Seniors are invited to enjoy a viewing of the compilation video created during the individual graduation ceremonies. We hope to see all of our Seniors there. This event will be on Saturday, July 18th, 2020. The East parking lot will be open to graduates at 8:30pm, and the screening will begin at 9pm. Graduates are restricted to one car each and are expected to practice safe, social distancing protocols.

We are so honored and excited to present this video to our Seniors and are looking forward to seeing everyone there. If a Senior is unable to attend, he or she will have the ability to watch the video online or download at his or her convenience. This option is also available to all family members.

Chatham Police Department
May 11 at 8:27 PM ¬∑

We had a first today.

During normal times, at the end of every school semester, we give presentations to the Government classes at Glenwood High School. Typically, they receive a K9 demonstration from Officer Jacob Bouldin and his partner, Dagz, a presentation on DUI's from Sergeant Mark Poani, and a presentation on traffic stops and what to do if they get pulled over from Officer David Leach. With COVID-19 forcing the school closures, however, we were unable to give them in person this year. But the virus didn't stop us from having an opportunity to connect with the students and teach them. It just forced us to get creative and do it in a different way.

This afternoon, Officer David Leach and GHS teacher/coach David Hay gave a virtual presentation to 120 students via Zoom. We had a few bugs to work out, but, we all had a few good laughs too. By and large, the presentation went pretty well!

And this was sent our way by Mr. Niemeyer - Music Teacher at BES: "It's obviously been hard on all of us. I've noticed from my own kids how hard it is for them to express how this quarantine has affected them. So I thought why not try and give them a voice? And a song? What better genre to express this than the blues?

So I had BES students fill out a Google Form answering the following questions...

-What is the one thing you miss doing the most during the quarantine?
-What is the one thing you miss about not being at school?
-Who is one adult you miss at school?

I took their responses and adapted them to the lyrics of the song made famous by Louis Armstrong and Billie Holiday - Do You Know What It Means to Miss New Orleans.

My good friend, bandmate, and SHG Music Director, Damien Kaplan, and I then recorded a version of this for you all.

I hope you enjoy!" ‚ù§Ô∏è

You may have noticed pinwheels popping up outside several of our schools, and wondered what it was about?

April is Child Abuse Prevention Month, and pinwheels are the symbol for child abuse prevention and awareness. This awareness couldn‚Äôt come at a better time, as many families may be dealing with multi-layered stresses during this unprecedented pandemic. Please know that our counselors at each school have numerous resources to help families. Students, our parents, and guardians are encouraged to reach out to them, or any of our teachers or administrators, if the stress is too much, and/or are in danger of hurting themselves or others. In addition, our QuickTip online reporting tool (located on the top navigation bar on each webpage as well as on our app) is always available and always monitored.

Work completed during this time will not be used for grading or assessment purposes.

Students cannot be penalized, or receive extra credit for work during this time.
